My experience with the CKAD exam

Getting from 0 to developer on Kubernetes in one month

11 September 2025
Machine Learning
Large Language Models

Who am I?

Hi, I am Giovanni, a ML engineer working on biomedical applications of machine learning and AI. Creating pipelines to manipulate data and train models takes up most of my normal workdays. You can read more about it in the About Me page.

I think that nowadays, to be an impactful engineer or developer, you need to be familiar with multiple levels of the abstractions that we use to run programs. I have always dedicated more time to specific software development topics (e.g. scaling ML models, implementing novel algorithms), but I have realized the value in understanding the big picture. If you do not know how to interface with the infrastructure, you will not understand how to train ML models on multiple GPUs, the best ways to schedule jobs and store results, and all of these ancillary tasks that are necessary to make a real impact in machine learning.

The Certified Kubernetes Application Developer (CKAD) exam

The CKAD exam is a certification offered by the Linux Foundation for developers using Kubernetes. In an effort to expand my knowledge of DevOps and systems engineering in general, I decided to take this certification as a challenge, starting from essentially 0 knowledge of K8s (but decent Docker experience). I want to share here my experience in case it can provide some useful guidance to other people aiming to upskill.

Preparation

For getting up to speed, I relied heavily on the courses by KodeKloud, which I accessed through Udemy. I started from the course Kubernetes for the Absolute Beginners, and completed it in 3 days. I then moved to the followup course Kubernetes Certified Application Developer (CKAD) with Tests](https://www.udemy.com/course/certified-kubernetes-application-developer/), which took me about 3 weeks to complete. In general, these courses provided a solid learning curve, with hands-on exercises that I found quite useful. If you are not experienced with Kubernetes, these were some really solid paths for me to follow.

After the courses, I repeated all the hands-on labs from the second course, and then moved to the test exam available through killer.sh, which is included when you sign up for the exam through the Linux Foundation.

All of these were sufficient for me, and I successfully passed the exam on the first try with a score of 87%.

The exam

The exam was mostly a smooth experience, with some checkin procedure beforehand for verifying that I did not have helpers, earphones, and other cheat material. For this reason, I recommend connecting ~20 minutes before the scheduled time. I was also in an advantageous position that I use neovim as my editor of choice, which made the exam significantly easier. During the test, you need to ssh into different machines, and setting up something like visual studio code would have been more cumbersome to me, while using the available vim editor I could speed through any task that required editing of YAML files.

I obviously cannot provide details on the exam itself, but I want to emphasize a few things that came handy:

  • pay attention to namespaces: ensuring that you create and access the objects in the correct namespace was often crucial
  • learn how to verify whether services are working, either from the nodes (with a simple curl or wget command), or from inside a Pod (by running a shell in a pod with kubectl exec -it <pod-name> -- /bin/bash).
  • Focus a lot on imperative commands. All the methods to create pods, secrets, configmaps, etc. saved a considerable amount of time.
  • A lot of other guides suggest edits to make to the .bashrc and .vimrc files, but considering how often I had to ssh into different machines, I did not find that approach useful.
  • You have access to the official K8s documentation, so learn how to find the important stuff. E.g. I could not remember the syntax for liveness probes, but I remembered the page and exactly where to find what I needed, so it barely slowed me down.

In general, I found the exercises on killer.sh to be quite a bit more difficult than the actual exam, so if you have good performance on those, you can proceed with confidence.

Reference links

Some material that I found useful to prepare the exam:

  • lucassha Github: CKAD-resources
  • dgkanatsios Github: CKAD exercises
  • Yang Lyu - Tips on passing CKAD exam
  • Shafath Ahmed - I passed CKAD: here is what you need to know
  • chdalski Github: CKAD exam preparation

If you are planning to take the exam, good luck with your endeavour!
